Project 1 - To do list - 2


Typescript learning

We put '!' in typescript for variables to say that we definitely wont get undefined value. But there can be possibility of undefined value in generic code at that time we should use '?' instead of '!'.

  1. @Input() name?:string;


In HTML

  1. <app-tasks [name]="selectedUser?.name" />


It simply says if the selectedUser.name is available use it else pass undefined to the tasks component. 

The type passing among variables is important in ts to avoid runtime error.

There is also an alternative approach.

  1. @Input() name: string | undefined;


It says either the name has string datatype value or it is undefined.

Getting Object as Input

We can get objects as the input instead of 3 different strings.

  1. #user.component.ts
  2.  @Input({required:true}) user!: { //getting object as input
  3.  id:string;
  4.  name:string;
  5.  avatar:string;
  6.  }

  8.  @Output() select = new EventEmitter<string>();
  9.  get imagePath(){
  10.    return 'assets/users/' + this.user.avatar; //using the value from the object
  11.  }
  12.  onSelectUser(){
  13.    this.select.emit(this.user.id);
  14.  }


  1. #user.component.html
  2. <div>
  3.    <button (click)="onSelectUser()">
  4.        <img [src]="imagePath" [alt]="user.name"/> //using in UI
  5.        <span>{{user.name}}</span>
  6.    </button>
  7. </div>


  1. #app.component.html
  2. <app-header></app-header>
  3. <main>
  4.  <ul id="users">
  5.    <li>
  6.      <app-user [user]="users[0]" (select)="onSelectUser($event)"/> //passing the user object to the user component
  7.    </li>
  8.    <li>
  9.      <app-user [user]="users[1]" (select)="onSelectUser($event)"/>
  10.    </li>
  11.    <li>
  12.      <app-user [user]="users[2]" (select)="onSelectUser($event)"/>
  13.    </li>
  14.    <li>
  15.      <app-user [user]="users[3]" (select)="onSelectUser($event)"/>
  16.    </li>
  17.  </ul>
  18.  <app-tasks [name]="selectedUser.name"/>
  19. </main>


Type Alias

Some times there can be many key value pair in the object or the type should be given to more than 1 variable so defining that in the @Input can be complex. We can create type commonly outside and can be given to the variables in @Input.

  1. #user.component.ts
  2. type User = {
  3.  id:string;
  4.  name:string;
  5.  avatar:string;
  6.  }
  7. @Component({
  8.  selector: 'app-user',
  9.  standalone: true,
  10.  imports: [],
  11.  templateUrl: './user.component.html',
  12.  styleUrl: './user.component.css'
  13. })
  14. export class UserComponent {
  15.  @Input({required:true}) user!: User; 

  17.  @Output() select = new EventEmitter<string>();
  18.  get imagePath(){
  19.    return 'assets/users/' + this.user.avatar;
  20.  }
  21.  onSelectUser(){
  22.    this.select.emit(this.user.id);
  23.  }


We can also use interface instead of type.

  1. #user.component.ts
  2. interface User {
  3.  id:string;
  4.  name:string;
  5.  avatar:string;
  6.  }
  7. @Component({
  8.  selector: 'app-user',
  9.  standalone: true,
  10.  imports: [],
  11.  templateUrl: './user.component.html',
  12.  styleUrl: './user.component.css'
  13. })
  14. export class UserComponent {
  15.  @Input({required:true}) user!: User; 

  17.  @Output() select = new EventEmitter<string>();
  18.  get imagePath(){
  19.    return 'assets/users/' + this.user.avatar;
  20.  }
  21.  onSelectUser(){
  22.    this.select.emit(this.user.id);
  23.  }


The Major difference between type and interface is in interface we can only define object type where in type we can define any type.

Other differences between type and interface can we found in - type vs interface .

Outputting List Content

Instead of hard coding all the index of list as separate component we are going to use loop to show them dynamically.

Syntax - @for(value of array){ //code }

It will throw a error "for loop must have a 'track' expression"

To fix that 

@for(value of array; track value.key) { //code }

Why we need track in loop?

When we dynamically displaying the array the angular need to track the array for any shuffle or changes so angular could easily reuse already rendered items instead of re rendering it. We need to mention unique id per value to the track so it will be helpful for angular to update the list items when it is changed.

  1. #app.component.html
  2. <ul id="users">
  3.    @for (user of users; track user.id) { //here user.id is the unique value.
  4.      <li>
  5.      <app-user [user]="user" (select)="onSelectUser($event)"/>
  6.      </li>
  7.    }
  8.  </ul>


Conditional Content

Initially when opening the to do app we dont select any users but the tasks component is rendered with empty value. To avoid this we need conditions to render the component.

We have conditional content @if like the loop.

syntax - @if(condition){ //code }

  1. #app.component.ts
  2. export class AppComponent {
  3.  users = DUMMY_USERS;
  4.  selectedUserId?:string; //the value is not initialized so it can produce undefined.

  6.  get selectedUser(){
  7.    return this.users.find((user) => user.id === this.selectedUserId);
  8.  }

  10.  onSelectUser(id:string){
  11.    this.selectedUserId = id;
  12.    
  13.  }
  14. }


  1. #app.component.html
  2.  @if (selectedUser) {
  3.    <app-tasks [name]="selectedUser.name"/>
  4.  }


So in this case we dont need '?.' because the angular knows the undefined value cant be passed to tasks component because of the if.

There is also @else and @else if blocks are available in angular.

  1. #app.component.html
  2. @if (selectedUser) {
  3.    <app-tasks [name]="selectedUser.name"/>
  4.  } @else {
  5.    <p id="fallback">Select a user to see their tasks!</p>
  6.  }


The above method of for and if is the new which is added in Angular 17. Let's see the older syntax.

Older For and If

The older version of for loop is ngFor.

syntax - *ngFor="let value of array"

This is called as structural directives. Structural directives are enhancements that are added to the elements like <li> that will change the DOM where those elements are used.

To use *ngFor in the template need to import it in respective ts file. Import NgFor from '@angular/common' and add it to the imports is @Component decorator.

The modern @for and @if is not structural directives so it dont want to be imported.

Instead of @if we can use ngIf.

*ngIf="condition"

For else we have special syntax. The else code should be written inside a <ng-template> element provided by angular and the ng-template should have a identifier say #fallback and this identifier is called inside the else.

syntax - *ngIf="condition; else fallback"

Like NgFor the NgIf also should be imported in ts file.

  1. #app.component.html
  2. <app-header></app-header>
  3. <main>
  4.  <ul id="users">
  5.    <li *ngFor="let user of users">
  6.    <app-user [user]="user" (select)="onSelectUser($event)"/>
  7.    </li>
  8.  </ul>
  9.  <app-tasks *ngIf="selectedUser; else fallback" [name]="selectedUser!.name"/> #'!' should be used since this method cant tell undefied.
  10.  <ng-template #fallback> #fallback is the identifier
  11.    <p id="fallback">Select a user to see their tasks!</p>
  12.  </ng-template>
  13. </main> 


  1. #app.component.ts
  2. import { NgFor, NgIf } from '@angular/common';

  4. @Component({
  5.  selector: 'app-root',
  6.  standalone: true,
  7.  imports: [RouterOutlet, HeaderComponent, UserComponent, TasksComponent, NgFor, NgIf], #NgFor and NgIf is imported
  8.  templateUrl: './app.component.html',
  9.  styleUrl: './app.component.css'
  10. })


We can use any of the methods in our code.

Tasks Component

Now we are gonna work on tasks component and display every tasks of the user clicked.

We want to create another component task which displays all the individual task inside the tasks folder. Using cli

  1. ng g c tasks/task


Create a dummy array of tasks in the tasks.component.ts and use getter method to filter the tasks of the particular user when it is clicked by passing the clicked user id from app component to the tasks component.

  1. #tasks.component.ts
  2. export class TasksComponent {
  3. @Input({required:true}) userId!:string;
  4. @Input({required:true}) name!:string;
  5. tasks = [     //dummy array of tasks
  6.  {
  7.    id: 't1',
  8.    userId: 'u1',
  9.    title: 'Master Angular',
  10.    summary:
  11.      'Learn all the basic and advanced features of Angular & how to apply them.',
  12.    dueDate: '2025-12-31',
  13.  },
  14.  {
  15.    id: 't2',
  16.    userId: 'u3',
  17.    title: 'Build first prototype',
  18.    summary: 'Build a first prototype of the online shop website',
  19.    dueDate: '2024-05-31',
  20.  },
  21.  {
  22.    id: 't3',
  23.    userId: 'u3',
  24.    title: 'Prepare issue template',
  25.    summary:
  26.      'Prepare and describe an issue template which will help with project management',
  27.    dueDate: '2024-06-15',
  28.  },
  29. ]

  31. get selectedUserTasks(){
  32.  return this.tasks.filter((task) => task.userId === this.userId); //to filter and return the array of tasks of particular user with the userId clicked.
  33. }
  34. }


  1. #app.component.html
  2.  @if (selectedUser) {
  3.    <app-tasks [name]="selectedUser.name" [userId]="selectedUser.id"/> //id is passed to tasks component
  4.  } @else {
  5.    <p id="fallback">Select a user to see their tasks!</p>
  6.  }


  1. #tasks.component.html
  2.  <ul>
  3.        @for (task of selectedUserTasks; track task.id) { //loop to send tasks to task component. selectedUserTasks is the getter that filtered tasks based on userId.
  4.            <li>
  5.                <app-task />
  6.            </li>
  7.        }
  8.  </ul>


Now we want to pass the tasks to the task component.

  1. #tasks.component.html
  2. @for (task of selectedUserTasks; track task.id) {
  3.            <li>
  4.                <app-task [task]="task"/> //binding task object to the input and passing to task component
  5.            </li>
  6.  }


  1. #task.component.ts
  2. import { Component, Input } from '@angular/core';

  4. interface Task{ //creating interface for the object
  5.  id: string,
  6.  userId: string,
  7.  title: string,
  8.  summary: string,
  9.  dueDate: string
  10. }
  11. @Component({
  12.  selector: 'app-task',
  13.  standalone: true,
  14.  imports: [],
  15.  templateUrl: './task.component.html',
  16.  styleUrl: './task.component.css'
  17. })
  18. export class TaskComponent {
  19.  @Input({required:true}) task!:Task; 

  21. }


  1. #task.component.html
  2. <article>
  3.    <h2>{{task.title}}</h2>
  4.    <time>{{task.dueDate}}</time>
  5.    <p>
  6.        {{task.summary}}
  7.    </p>
  8.    <p class="actions">
  9.        <button>Complete</button>
  10.    </p>
  11. </article>


Models

We used interface or type for the inputs of objects but in angular it is best to outsource these type of inputs to the separate file called model. Create user.model.ts under user folder it is best to keep the model files under their respective component folder.

To make those models available outside the file we need to export it.

  1. #user.model.ts
  2. export interface User {
  3.    id:string;
  4.    name:string;
  5.    avatar:string;
  6. }


Now we can use this User type in any file we need.

Now just import the model file in the requried component to make it work.

  1. #user.component.ts
  2. import { User } from './user.model';


To let others know that we only importing type definition we can explicitly mention type keyword before User.

  1. #user.component.ts
  2. import { type User } from './user.model';


Similarly create Task model.

Dynamic CSS styling

When a user is selected it will be good to highlight that user in the user component. We can dynamically add the .active class which is defined in user.component.css.

  1. #user.component.ts
  2.  @Input({required:true}) selected!:boolean; //input to know whether the user is selected or not.


  1. #app.component.html
  2. @for (user of users; track user.id) {
  3.      <li>
  4.      <app-user [user]="user" [selected]="user.id === selectedUserId" (select)="onSelectUser($event)"/> //selected boolean is binded.
  5.      </li>
  6.  }


Now we need to bind the class property in the html instead of binding entire class we can bind the particular class name by [class.class_name]

  1. #user.component.html
  2. <div>
  3.    <button [class.active]="selected" (click)="onSelectUser()"> //binding the property
  4.        <img [src]="imagePath" [alt]="user.name"/>
  5.        <span>{{user.name}}</span>
  6.    </button>
  7. </div>


Output is below

Now lets make the complete button work.

When the complete button is clicked the id of the task should be emitted from the task component to the tasks component where it should be removed from the array.

  1. #task.component.html
  2. <p class="actions">
  3.        <button (click)="onCompleteTask()">Complete</button> #event is triggered on clicking the complete button
  4.  </p>


  1. #task.component.ts
  2.  @Output() complete = new EventEmitter<string>();

  4.  onCompleteTask(){
  5.    this.complete.emit(this.task.id); //task id is emitted to parent component
  6.  }


  1. #tasks.component.html
  2. @for (task of selectedUserTasks; track task.id) {
  3.            <li>
  4.                <app-task [task]="task" (complete)="onCompleteTask($event)"/> #catching the complete event in the parent component.
  5.            </li>
  6.  }


  1. #tasks.component.ts
  2. onCompleteTask(id:string){
  3.  this.tasks = this.tasks.filter((task) => task.id !== id); //it will only return the tasks which id not equal to the one from the completed clicked.
  4. }


Add Task

Create new-task component inside the tasks folder.

  1. ng g c tasks/new-task --skio-tests //to skip the test file


Now we need to show NewTaskComponent only when the Add button is clicked to do that we need to initialize a boolean in tasks component and make it true when add task button is clicked and user new task component in tasks component when that boolean is true.

  1. #tasks.component.ts
  2. isAddingTask = false; //typescript automatically knows the type when value is given
  3. onStartAddTask(){ //method call when add button clicked
  4.  this.isAddingTask = true;
  5. }


  1. #tasks.component.html
  2. <menu>
  3.            <button (click)="onStartAddTask()">Add Task</button>
  4.  </menu>

  6.  @if (isAddingTask) {
  7.        <app-new-task /> //displaying the new component when it is true
  8.  }


Close New Task Dialogbox

When the cancel button or the backdrop is clicked on the new task form it should be closed. To do that we have to make isAddingTask = false when cancel button or backdrop is clicked.

  1. #new-task.component.html
  2. <div class="backdrop" (click)="onCancelTask()"></div> #method called when clicking
  3. <dialog open>
  4.  <h2>Add Task</h2>
  5.  <form>
  6.    <p>
  7.      <label for="title">Title</label>
  8.      <input type="text" id="title" name="title" />
  9.    </p>

  11.    <p>
  12.      <label for="summary">Summary</label>
  13.      <textarea id="summary" rows="5" name="summary"></textarea>
  14.    </p>

  16.    <p>
  17.      <label for="due-date">Due Date</label>
  18.      <input type="date" id="due-date" name="due-date" />
  19.    </p>

  21.    <p class="actions">
  22.      <button type="button" (click)="onCancelTask()">Cancel</button> #method called when clicking
  23.      <button type="submit">Create</button>
  24.    </p>
  25.  </form>
  26. </dialog>


  1. #new-task.component.ts
  2. import { Component, EventEmitter, Output } from '@angular/core';

  4. @Component({
  5.  selector: 'app-new-task',
  6.  standalone: true,
  7.  imports: [],
  8.  templateUrl: './new-task.component.html',
  9.  styleUrl: './new-task.component.css'
  10. })
  11. export class NewTaskComponent {
  12. @Output() cancel = new EventEmitter<void>(); //since its not emitting any data void type

  14. onCancelTask(){
  15.  this.cancel.emit();
  16. }
  17. }


  1. #tasks.component.html
  2. @if (isAddingTask) {
  3.    <app-new-task (cancel)="onCancelAddTask()"/> //catching that event emitted
  4. }


  1. #tasks.component.ts
  2. onCancelAddTask(){
  3.  this.isAddingTask = false;
  4. }


Directives and Two Way Binding

Two way binding is nothing but binding both properties and the events

Now lets create a variable enteredTitle = ' '; Now we need to update the value for this variable when user starts typing the title.

To do that we should use ngModel directive to the respective element in the HTML.

Directives are nothing but a angular feature which is used to enhance the elements.

Components are directives with template. Directives dont have template.

ngModel is the directive provided by angular to be used in <input>, <textarea> or other form related inputs to get the value that are being entered in the element.

syntax of two way binding - [(ngModel)]

No other element which is not provided by angular supports 2 way binding.

simply 2 way binding will bing both typing event and also the property of the input element.

Also 2 way binding will give access to value entered into input field by the user and also write data back to the input.

ngModel should be given to the property to bind in this case its enteredTtile.

[(ngModel)]="enteredTtile"

ngModel need to imported in ts file like ngFor and ngIf. We need to import FormsModule in ts file it is a collection of forms related directives.

See the example below for clear understanding of 2 way binding 

  1. <p>
  2.      <label for="title">Title</label>
  3.      <input type="text" id="title" name="title" [(ngModel)]="enteredTitle"/>
  4.  </p>
  5. <p>
  6.      <label for="title2">Title</label>
  7.      <input type="text" id="title2" name="title2" [(ngModel)]="enteredTitle"/>
  8.  </p>


Since the enteredTitle is binded 2 way when the data is entered in the first input it will automatically written the data into 2nd input field also so it both reads (from 1st) and writes (to 2nd).

Note: inputs in html will always yield string value even if it is of different type like date, etc.

  1. #new-task.component.ts
  2. export class NewTaskComponent {
  3. @Output() cancel = new EventEmitter<void>();
  4. enteredTitle ='';
  5. enteredSummary = '';
  6. enteredDate = '';

  8. onCancelTask(){
  9.  this.cancel.emit();
  10. }


  1. #new-task.component.html
  2. <p>
  3.      <label for="title">Title</label>
  4.      <input type="text" id="title" name="title" [(ngModel)]="enteredTitle"/> //2 way binding
  5.    </p>

  7.    <p>
  8.      <label for="summary">Summary</label>
  9.      <textarea id="summary" rows="5" name="summary" [(ngModel)]="enteredSummary"></textarea>
  10.    </p>

  12.    <p>
  13.      <label for="due-date">Due Date</label>
  14.      <input type="date" id="due-date" name="due-date" [(ngModel)]="enteredDate"/>
  15.  </p>


Two Way Binding Using Signals

No need to change anything in html file.

  1. #new-task.component.ts
  2. export class NewTaskComponent {
  3. @Output() cancel = new EventEmitter<void>();
  4. enteredTitle = signal(''); //need to be imported
  5. enteredSummary = signal('');
  6. enteredDate = signal('');

  8. onCancelTask(){
  9.  this.cancel.emit();
  10. }
  11. }


No need to be use ( ) for signal value in html like before it wont be supported in 2 way binding.
